text: 1 The Joyful Curse.
Name: Book 28

text: Where do you think the Haze comes from.
Name: Book 28

text: I dont think about it at all.
Name: Book 28

text: Why not.
Name: Book 28

text: Why should I.
Name: Book 28

text: The brother and sister strolled the hillsides beyond the grand Dearen palace.
Name: Book 28

text: As heirs to the throne of Dearen, Kyne and Fayr Violeni spent more of their time within the palace than without.
Name: Book 28

text: Today they took the rare opportunity to stare at their home from afar.
Name: Book 28

text: From a distance, it became more obvious that the soft glowing Haze covering the whole land of Dearen lay most thickly upon their own royal abode.
Name: Book 28

text: What made this fog distinct from any other in the world was the magic substance that floated within it: a glittering dust known as safra.
Name: Book 28

text: Safra brought intense pleasure and joy to anyone who consumed itanyone, that is, but for the few remaining members of the royal Violenese bloodline.
Name: Book 28

text: The large fortress glittered like a pile of jewels in the distance.
Name: Book 28

text: Part of the palaces charm was its inconsistency; some sections gleamed with deep silver stone, others with crystalline pillars, while yet more sections dazzled the eye with inset gems.
Name: Book 28

text: The sprawled structure was a compilation of sections built by different cultures and peoples, all of whom came to Dearen for a pinch of the safra obtained from the Haze.
Name: Book 28

text: But as young Prince Kyne had observed, the beauty of the palace was offset by the coils of smoke drifting from its surface.
Name: Book 28

text: Sometimes, the smoke had a beauty of its own.
Name: Book 28

text: Tiny pieces of debris caught the sunshine and sparkled with brilliance.
Name: Book 28

text: Across the vast landscape, the rolling Haze diffused the light and made the entire land glow as if with an enchanted fog.
Name: Book 28

text: Do you think safra creates the Haze, or the Haze creates safra.
Name: Book 28

text: asked Kyne.
Name: Book 28

text: His eyes opened wide with wonder, even though his purple hair lashed sharply against his face.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr turned up her sharp little nose, enjoying how highly she towered over her brother.
Name: Book 28

text: She had just turned eighteen.
Name: Book 28

text: He was not yet thirteen years of age.
Name: Book 28

text: She liked to think she knew a lot more about the world than he did, although at times like this, the difference seemed slight.
Name: Book 28

text: She had to take pride in what little knowledge she had, or else spurn it altogether.
Name: Book 28

text: The Haze always has safra in it.
Name: Book 28

text: They are both created, simultaneously, by something else.
Name: Book 28

text: At least, that seems obvious enough to me.
Name: Book 28

text: Then what creates them.
Name: Book 28

text: You already asked that.
Name: Book 28

text: Not exactly.
Name: Book 28

text: Anyway, you didnt answer.
Name: Book 28

text: Nor will I ever.
Name: Book 28

text: You sound like a commoner, asking such foolish questions.
Name: Book 28

text: Why is it foolish.
Name: Book 28

text: Why cant we ask where the safra comes from.
Name: Book 28

text: Because we cant.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr began to feel flustered by the conversation.
Name: Book 28

text: Once upon a time, she pondered the same questions as her younger brother.
Name: Book 28

text: In truth, she still did sometimes.
Name: Book 28

text: But she gave up asking them a long time ago.
Name: Book 28

text: Better not to ask such things; better not to think of them at all.
Name: Book 28

text: A wind blew and made the Haze ripple across the landscape.
Name: Book 28

text: As she breathed the fresh air, Fayr realized something strange.
Name: Book 28

text: For just a moment, she smelled the air as it should smell: pure, without safra.
Name: Book 28

text: And it smelled wonderful.
Name: Book 28

text: Look over there, said Fayr suddenly.
Name: Book 28

text: Did you see that.
Name: Book 28

text: See what.
Name: Book 28

text: Over there.
Name: Book 28

text: The Haze was settling again, but in one area, it remained thin enough to see through.
Name: Book 28

text: What is it.
Name: Book 28

text: I think those are the cliffs of Vikand.
Name: Book 28

text: Are you sure.
Name: Book 28

text: He strained, as she did, to stare through the silver grip of the Haze.
Name: Book 28

text: But there, on the edge of the foggy horizon, lay a large shadow, slicing the smoke with sharp black crags.
Name: Book 28

text: How could it be.
Name: Book 28

text: I thought Vikand was further away.
Name: Book 28

text: Dearen is a small place, physically, said Fayr.
Name: Book 28

text: Havent you paid any attention to Jayns lectures.
Name: Book 28

text: Yes, but.
Name: Book 28

text: The entire kingdom of Dearen can be crossed in a day on horseback.
Name: Book 28

text: Are we really so small.
Name: Book 28

text: Prince Kynes little face drooped at the thought.
Name: Book 28

text: She put a hand on his velvety shoulder.
Name: Book 28

text: Only in size, brother.
Name: Book 28

text: And yet we are the most powerful kingdom in the world.
Name: Book 28

text: Dont let it bother you.
Name: Book 28

text: He seemed comforted by this, although he could not rip his eyes from the looming shadow of Vikand.
Name: Book 28

text: Lets get closer to it, said Fayr.
Name: Book 28

text: The mere thought set her heart pounding.
Name: Book 28

text: She didnt answer, but turned and made her way to the dense grove of lemon trees where theyd tethered their horses.
Name: Book 28

text: She looked down at herself, watched the undulating colors of her skirt ripple beneath her, and pondered the strange sensations roiling through her body.
Name: Book 28

text: She relished the quickening of her heart and the warm excitement in her belly.
Name: Book 28

text: And that wind  why had it smelled so good.
Name: Book 28

text: Shed lived in the palace all her life.
Name: Book 28

text: She was accustomed to the strange Haze that made most people happy.
Name: Book 28

text: Most people said it smelled like roses.
Name: Book 28

text: But now that she was further away from it, she wondered if it stank.
Name: Book 28

text: A strand of purple hair fell into her vision and she reached to brush it back.
Name: Book 28

text: It reminded her that she was not like most people in more ways than one.
Name: Book 28

text: The violet hair shared by herself, her brother, and her father made them different from anyone else in the world.
Name: Book 28

text: It indicated their ancient heritage, and thus their distinct inability to enjoy safra.
Name: Book 28

text: In the silky soft shade of the grove, she found their horses.
Name: Book 28

text: There were three steeds in all: two white palfreys for herself and the prince, and a gray destrier for Sir Gornum of the royal guard.
Name: Book 28

text: The guardian himself lay spread under a berry bush, his bearded mouth hanging open, his large eyes closed in sleep.
Name: Book 28

text: He wore no armor, only studded cloth, for who needed armor in Dearen.
Name: Book 28

text: She hoped the studs jabbed him as she kicked his drooping belly.
Name: Book 28

text: She sent a scowl to her brother, who trailed doggedly behind her.
Name: Book 28

text: You gave him too much safra.
Name: Book 28

text: Father told me to.
Name: Book 28

text: He told you to reward him with safra, small pinches at a time, and only after he has completed each service.
Name: Book 28

text: That is how it works.
Name: Book 28

text: Why cant you ever get it right.
Name: Book 28

text: Oh.
Name: Book 28

text: Kynes nose crinkled a little.
Name: Book 28

text: What are you doing now.
Name: Book 28

text: She grabbed his chin and forced him to look at her.
Name: Book 28

text: Are you about to cry.
Name: Book 28

text: Of course not.
Name: Book 28

text: But the moisture in his eyes betrayed him.
Name: Book 28

text: I cant believe you, Kyne.
Name: Book 28

text: If Father saw you right now, or if he heard the sort of questions you were asking.
Name: Book 28

text: Please dont tell him.
Name: Book 28

text: His blinks became more rapid and violent.
Name: Book 28

text: She shook her head and clicked her tongue reproachfully.
Name: Book 28

text: Not this time, I wont.
Name: Book 28

text: She moved to her horse, grabbed the saddle, and climbed upon its back.

frame.Frame: Cause change of position on a scale

Name: Book 28

text: Are we going back home now.
Name: Book 28

text: asked Kyne.
Name: Book 28

text: She huffed as she settled her skirts about her.
Name: Book 28

text: The heavy jewelry upon her neck and wrists only made her movements awkward.
Name: Book 28

text: She resisted an impulse to rip them all off.
Name: Book 28

text: I want to go further.
Name: Book 28

text: Father wont like that at all.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr flung her head back and breathed deeply of the air.
Name: Book 28

text: Can you smell it, little brother.
Name: Book 28

text: I didnt realize it until now.
Name: Book 28

text: It stinks.
Name: Book 28

text: Mother says it smells like jasmine.
Name: Book 28

text: Their mother was not like the two of them.
Name: Book 28

text: She was their mother, of course.
Name: Book 28

text: But she did not have the Violenese blood of their father.
Name: Book 28

text: She did not share the bright purple hair of her husband and children.
Name: Book 28

text: Does it smell that way to you.
Name: Book 28

text: Well.
Name: Book 28

text: He bowed his head, letting his short purple locks fall over his brow.
Name: Book 28

text: I suppose not.
Name: Book 28

text: Come on then.
Name: Book 28

text: Her horse could feel her impatience.
Name: Book 28

text: She pulled on the reins as the beast writhed beneath her.
Name: Book 28

text: Lets go just a little further.
Name: Book 28

text: Lets get away from the safra.
Name: Book 28

text: But Father says the Haze covers all of Dearen.
Name: Book 28

text: Then well get closer to the cliffs of Vikand.
Name: Book 28

text: What about Gornum.
Name: Book 28

text: Never mind him.
Name: Book 28

text: If the Haze covers all of Dearen, then it will protect us as always.
Name: Book 28

text: She did not wait for him, but kicked her horse and bounded forward.
Name: Book 28

text: She did not even care if he followed.
Name: Book 28

text: Now that she had caught a whiff of fresh air, she wanted more.
Name: Book 28

text: She wanted it like a horse wants water after running for miles.
Name: Book 28

text: All her life, she had lived in the safra-infused Haze and endured it.
Name: Book 28

text: While it intoxicated everyone else with joy, it blinded her with its constant glow.
Name: Book 28

text: The stench, which shed breathed so long that she stopped noticing it, had been suffocating her since birth.
Name: Book 28

text: Now she needed to escape, if only for a moment.
Name: Book 28

text: She needed to breathe pure air.
Name: Book 28

text: She did not know if she would find such purity any closer to the cliffs of Vikand.
Name: Book 28

text: But it seemed worth a try.
Name: Book 28

text: The palfreys white hooves thudded down the slope and into a thickening stretch of trees.
Name: Book 28

text: The cliffs of Vikand always seemed to cast a long shadow over the Dearen valleys underneath, even if the sun shone upon them.
Name: Book 28

text: For this reason, the forest growing beneath them was called the Shadowed Woods.
Name: Book 28

text: The tree limbs cast shapes like intertwined hands across the soft auburn soil.
Name: Book 28

text: Dandelion tufts from the meadows floated through the air and brushed her skin as she passed.
Name: Book 28

text: The darkness wrapped around her and sent a chill down her back.
Name: Book 28

text: For some reason, she liked it.
Name: Book 28

text: She glanced over her shoulder and saw her brother galloping after her.
Name: Book 28

text: He would catch up to her, or he wouldnt.
Name: Book 28

text: The only creatures in the woods were birds and tigers, and the latter never attacked Dearen natives: only strangers.
Name: Book 28

text: Whether the siblings got separated or not, neither of them faced any danger.
Name: Book 28

text: A dark shape flitted past her vision.
Name: Book 28

text: For a moment, she felt fear.
Name: Book 28

text: But almost as quickly as it came, the fear dissipated.
Name: Book 28

text: She had thought she saw a man in strange leather clothes.
Name: Book 28

text: For a moment he had seemed to glitter, but of course this was probably a consequence of the safra in the air.
Name: Book 28

text: Even here, deep in the Shadowed Woods, safra hovered about, drifting and sparkling.
Name: Book 28

text: In one sense, its presence continued to irritate her.
Name: Book 28

text: But on the other, she was relieved, because wherever there was safra, there was safety.
Name: Book 28

text: It was a tremendous blessing, even if sometimes it felt like a curse.
Name: Book 28

text: Her horse neighed and flung Fayr from its back.
Name: Book 28

text: As she flew through the air, she watched the soil rise up to meet her, and in that moment before she struck, she pondered what had happened.
Name: Book 28

text: A breath ago, she and her horse had thundered through the forest with a perfect rhythm.
Name: Book 28

text: The shadows danced, the safra blurred by, and her hair trailed behind her in soft purple streams, unable to keep up with her momentum.
Name: Book 28

text: Now everything stopped, and her hair spilled ahead of her.
Name: Book 28

text: Her cry became lost in the soil as she smacked against the dirt.
Name: Book 28

text: Pain.
Name: Book 28

text: Pain.
Name: Book 28

text: Pain.
Name: Book 28

text: She forgot that anything else existed.
Name: Book 28

text: Then she heard the moans of her horse.
Name: Book 28

text: She also heard the snapping of twigs as something crept towards her.
Name: Book 28

text: The second sound came from the opposite direction.
Name: Book 28

text: With a groan, she tried to rise up.
Name: Book 28

text: She wondered how long she had been lying there, and how badly she was hurt.
Name: Book 28

text: But more importantly, what had happened.
Name: Book 28

text: Horses were rarely so clumsy as to fall like that.
Name: Book 28

text: She saw the beautiful white beast sprawled in the dirt some distance from her.
Name: Book 28

text: Crimson blood rolled down its leg.
Name: Book 28

text: A leather hand wrapped around her mouth and nostrils.
Name: Book 28

text: A knee struck her between the shoulder-blades and pushed her back down.
Name: Book 28

text: The pain was excruciating, but she couldnt scream.
Name: Book 28

text: She couldnt even breathe.
Name: Book 28

text: Tears filled her eyes, blurring her vision.
Name: Book 28

text: Even through the watery ripples, she saw the white shape of her brother riding closer.
Name: Book 28

text: The voice of her captor was as deep and grating as metal against stone.
Name: Book 28

text: It also sounded muffled, as if he spoke through a mask.
Name: Book 28

text: She wriggled and thrashed, but this only tightened his grip on her.
Name: Book 28

text: He flung her around, pressing her back against the earth.
Name: Book 28

text: He straddled her chest, and if she could have, she would have screamed with terror as she looked up at him.
Name: Book 28

text: He was the same man she glimpsed running through the trees.
Name: Book 28

text: He wore a tight suit of leather, and indeed it did glitter, but not because of any safra.
Name: Book 28

text: It glittered because it was covered with metal spikes, small but sharp.
Name: Book 28

text: A mask covered his face, shaped and painted to resemble a wolfs.
Name: Book 28

text: Through two small holes she saw his real eyes, glinting with a cruel shade of red.
Name: Book 28

text: Cold metal pressed to her neck.
Name: Book 28

text: This surprised her because he did not seem to be holding something as large as a knife.
Name: Book 28

text: Call him here, or you die now.
Name: Book 28

text: He let go of her, but for a moment, the weight of her fear kept her paralyzed.
Name: Book 28

text: She was too dizzy and frightened to breathe, let alone make a decision.
Name: Book 28

text: As soon as she was capable, she screamed.
Name: Book 28

text: He struck her in the face.
Name: Book 28

text: Her head rattled as she thrashed again.
Name: Book 28

text: But his strength pressed her down, and she glimpsed the flash of his weapona curved metal shardas he returned it to her neck.
Name: Book 28

text: This time she knew he would kill her.
Name: Book 28

text: A pale shape arose behind her captor.
Name: Book 28

text: For a ridiculous moment, Fayr thought her horse was coming to her rescue.
Name: Book 28

text: Then she realized that it was a man wearing blue, except for his hat, which was full of colorful feathers.
Name: Book 28

text: He did not seem like a typical hero in the least: he was slender of build, dark of skin, and his clothes seemed almost clownish.
Name: Book 28

text: But she did not have a chance now to consider his strange appearance, nor his choice of attire; all that mattered was that he had managed to sneak up on the man in the wolf-mask, then whack him over the head with a large stick.
Name: Book 28

text: Her rescuer struck in such a way that the wolf-mask cracked and fell off.
Name: Book 28

text: The man growled and reached for it, but too late to catch it.
Name: Book 28

text: Much of his face remained hidden, nonetheless, for he wore a handkerchief over his nose and mouth.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayrs hero grabbed the handkerchief, using it to yank the assassin backwards.
Name: Book 28

text: Safra.
Name: Book 28

text: cried the fellow in the feather-hat.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr scrambled to obey as her captor and protector fought against each other.
Name: Book 28

text: The man in the wolf-mask had been caught by surprise, but he was regaining control of himself quickly.
Name: Book 28

text: As the feathery fellow pulled at the kerchief, working to undo it, the wolf-man twirled the naked metal across his gloves.
Name: Book 28

text: His red eyes flicked to his opponents feet, which he aimed for with his strange weapon.
Name: Book 28

text: While all of this happened, Fayr pulled a pouch of safra from her belt.
Name: Book 28

text: Now.
Name: Book 28

text: cried the rescuer, tearing off the kerchief.
Name: Book 28

text: It was almost as if it had all been pre-planned.
Name: Book 28

text: Just as the kerchief fell away, baring the assassins mouth, Fayr opened the pouch and flung safra towards him.
Name: Book 28

text: A fountain of glittering dust sprayed into the villains face.
Name: Book 28

text: He gagged as he first breathed it in.
Name: Book 28

text: Then his entire body went slightly limp.
Name: Book 28

text: The blade fell from his fingers.
Name: Book 28

text: His lids grew heavy over his red irises.
Name: Book 28

text: He sagged forward, nearly falling upon Fayr with his leather suit of spikes.
Name: Book 28

text: Only chance, or perhaps luck, kept himself from doing so.
Name: Book 28

text: He caught himself with one hand.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr had a brief moment to stare into his face, a face wrinkled with age and scars, gleaming with red eyes that burned with fury even as the safra overcame him.
Name: Book 28

text: Then she wriggled out from under him.
Name: Book 28

text: The assassin fell against the soil, suspended slightly by the studs along his clothing.
Name: Book 28

text: Then he shook suddenly with laughter.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayrs hero crouched down beside her and put a gentle hand on her shoulder.
Name: Book 28

text: Are you all right, Princess.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr just gaped back at her strange savior.
Name: Book 28

text: Her whole body trembled against his touch.
Name: Book 28

text: She thought she might break into tears if she wasnt more careful.
Name: Book 28

text: She mustnt do that.
Name: Book 28

text: Her father was going to kill her already.
Name: Book 28

text: Best not to break his most adamant rule of all, which was to never cry in public, and thus reveal to everyone that safra had no effect on the few of royal blood.
Name: Book 28

text: Im fine, she gasped at last.
Name: Book 28

text: The man in the feather-hat smiled.
Name: Book 28

text: His black eyes softened and his muscles sagged with relief.
Name: Book 28

text: The safra in the air must have affected him, too.
Name: Book 28

text: Strange thing, isnt it.
Name: Book 28

text: I dont often take a stroll in the Shadowed Woods like this.
Name: Book 28

text: The one day I do, I find you, the princess herself, and then I save your life.
Name: Book 28

text: How very lovely.
Name: Book 28

text: Yes.
Name: Book 28

text: She forced a smile onto her face.
Name: Book 28

text: She had become very skilled at faking smiles, over the years.
Name: Book 28

text: What is your name.
Name: Book 28

text: Oh please, I am only a humble merchant.
Name: Book 28

text: Well then.
Name: Book 28

text: You will be rewarded with much safra.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr.
Name: Book 28

text: At long last, Kyne came galloping through the trees.
Name: Book 28

text: Next to him rode their sleepy guard, Gornum.
Name: Book 28

text: The princerather than Gornum, who seemed dazed enough to ride into oblivionpulled his horse to a lurching stop as he took in the scene before him.
Name: Book 28

text: First he caught sight of Fayrs fallen steed, then the Merchant in the feathered hat, and at last the would-be assassin, face-down in the dirt and shaking with giggles.
Name: Book 28

text: Kynes face turned bleached white.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr stood up and brushed off her satin dress, but it was her composure she straightened more than anything.
Name: Book 28

text: Somehow, she found it easiest to feign calmness around her little brother.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps because she did it for his own sake, too.
Name: Book 28

text: All is well.
Name: Book 28

text: Maybe it is now.
Name: Book 28

text: Kyne gulped, preparing himself to make his wisest statement yet.
Name: Book 28

text: But it wont be when Father hears of this.
Name: Book 28

text: * King Joyhan of Dearen was a short man with thick muscular build.
Name: Book 28

text: He had purple hair to his ears and a crown of gold and jewels softened round with furs.
Name: Book 28

text: Beneath the crown, his purple eyebrows knitted together in a scowl.
Name: Book 28

text: He ate his expensive meal of crab-meat with violent crunching and gnashing of his teeth.
Name: Book 28

text: Clearly he did not care to linger over the taste of the stuff, despite its worth in gold.
Name: Book 28

text: The royal family sat around a glass table within the Crystal Dining Hall.
Name: Book 28

text: Candlelight danced upon the walls and reflected the various colors of silk lining the ceiling.
Name: Book 28

text: In an adjacent hallway, a servant played chimes that reverberated through the chamber.
Name: Book 28

text: On the royal table lay a splendid smorgasbord of food from across the continent.
Name: Book 28

text: They had fish and crab roasted in honey-sauce, sliced melons and sugared berries.
Name: Book 28

text: Despite all this splendor, only one person at the table was cheerful.
Name: Book 28

text: This was the mother, Queen Lilyana: the only person at the table without purple hair.
Name: Book 28

text: She hummed quietly to herself between bites of food.
Name: Book 28

text: Her entire plate glittered with all the safra she had sprinkled over her meal like a spice.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr didnt even know why she bothered.
Name: Book 28

text: The Haze was so thick in the palace that most people were happy just breathing in the safra.
Name: Book 28

text: But then again, Fayr would probably never understand the happiness that safra gave most peopleeveryone, that is, but for herself, her brother, and her father.
Name: Book 28

text: King Joyhan ate out of duty and Queen Lilyana ate with delight.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr and Kyne, however, could not bring themselves to eat at all.
Name: Book 28

text: They had not yet touched a crumb of their own food.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr, at least, had an excuse: she had talked throughout the meal thus far, relating to her father what had happened that day as quickly and casually as possible.
Name: Book 28

text: Kyne, on the other hand, neither moved nor spoke at all, but stared at his plate and kept his mouth shut.
Name: Book 28

text: So, said King Joyhan, wiping his purple beard with cloth, what happened to this Merchant fellow.
Name: Book 28

text: Princess Fayr gulped, even though she had no food in her mouth to provide an excuse.
Name: Book 28

text: She had already explained the most traumatic event of her story and hoped she could stop there.
Name: Book 28

text: Back here in the safety of the Dearen palace, the entire incident seemed like a garish nightmare, hardly real.
Name: Book 28

text: She thought if only she had a moment alone, she might convince herself that it had all been a dream.
Name: Book 28

text: But the more her father questioned her about it, the more he forced her to accept its reality.
Name: Book 28

text: The Merchant, in his own way, was the most troubling memory of all, for his behavior had never made sense to her.
Name: Book 28

text: He, uh.
Name: Book 28

text: he left, she said at last.
Name: Book 28

text: Did you not offer him a reward for helping you.
Name: Book 28

text: Of course.
Name: Book 28

text: She squirmed in her seat, then poked at her food with a knife.
Name: Book 28

text: I suspect that when I flung safra on my attacker, the Merchant breathed some, also.
Name: Book 28

text: After a moment, he probably ceased to care about the future, for he was already so happy.
Name: Book 28

text: You know how it is.
Name: Book 28

text: Hm.
Name: Book 28

text: The king stopped eating and stared deeply into the table.
Name: Book 28

text: So far, he had offered very little reaction to her story.
Name: Book 28

text: This worried her more than if he had expressed his anger immediately.
Name: Book 28

text: Just as he had trained his children to restrain all unhappy emotions, so he had trained himself long ago.
Name: Book 28

text: As a result, the emotions built up inside of him until he could contain them no longer and they burst out in the ugliest fashion.
Name: Book 28

text: The longer his emotions built up, the worse the explosion.
Name: Book 28

text: What became of your horse.
Name: Book 28

text: The Merchant, um.
Name: Book 28

text: She coughed a little to loosen her throat.
Name: Book 28

text: The Merchant took it.

text: Wait.

text: We cant carry him.

text: Ah.

text: What.

text: This should do it.

Name: Book 28

text: And the Merchant had not stopped there: he next offered to care for Fayrs wounded horse and give her his own, a large speckled beast with black spots and long sweeping hair down its hooves and neck.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr had coveted the beautiful creature as soon as she saw it, and gladly accepted the Merchants offer.
Name: Book 28

text: Now that her father asked the same question, Fayr was desperate to change the subject, even if by doing so, she jumped to the next most unpleasant one.

text: What did her father know that he wasnt telling her.

Name: Book 28

text: What was he hiding.
Name: Book 28

text: Her voice was small and tight in her throat, but her desperation must have rang clearly enough, for the king of Dearen took pause.

text: Why was that man after us.

text: Fayr worried that he was coming up with a new way to steer her away from the truth.

text: Since her birth, he had contrived hundreds of ways to hide what he alone knew and no one else did.

text: Where did the safra come from.

text: Father, she said again.

text: She wasnt sure if she could hold back her sorrow any longer.
Name: Book 28

text: She needed to cry, and sometimes, her attempts to hold back only made it harder to do so.
Name: Book 28

text: How long must I wait before I understand what the hell is going on around here.

text: * On her way to the dungeons, Fayr wondered what she had gotten herself into.
Name: Book 28

text: She had never been to the dungeons before.
Name: Book 28

text: She knew they existed.

text: Occasionally, she saw people go into them.

Name: Book 28

text: There werent many criminals in Dearen.
Name: Book 28

text: People didnt tend to commit crimes when they were happy, and the Haze kept them all happy.
Name: Book 28

text: But she knew that every once in awhile, the king sent people down here.
Name: Book 28

text: It was one of those things she wasnt supposed to talk about.
Name: Book 28

text: The strangest part was that she never saw people come back out.
Name: Book 28

text: The king himself was the only one with the key.
Name: Book 28

text: This she knew also, for whenever people entered the dungeons, her father went with them.
Name: Book 28

text: Because of this unfortunate fact, their newly-acquired prisoner would have to enter tonight beside the king and his family.
Name: Book 28

text: Now, he sat with hands bound beside the large stone door with a guard on either side of him.
Name: Book 28

text: The royal family found him thus, slumped against the wall with his horrible suit hanging in tatters from his waist, his bare torso scraped and bruised, probably from contact with his own cruel weaponry.
Name: Book 28

text: The king stood over the prisoner, his cloak billowing outward as if to swallow him whole.
Name: Book 28

text: Youre a Wolven, arent you.

text: The man did not reply.
Name: Book 28

text: Once again, Fayr was surprised by his age; he was so fit that she would never have guessed how old he was from afar.

text: Wrinkles and scars criss-crossed across his expressionless face.

text: Show me the mask.

text: cried the king.

text: Here in the smoky light of the palace, it hardly looked threatening at all.

text: It was no longer the face of a ghoulish monster that had pushed her to the forest floor and pressed sharp metal to her neck.

text: You are a Wolven.

text: gasped the king.

text: I am going to slice you into a hundred pieces.

text: * They went to the topmost balcony, where the moon glowed behind the glittery veil of the Haze, and the purr of distant tigers rumbled through the darkness.

text: The king stared thoughtfully into the silver light.

text: It drained the color from his purple hair and beard.

text: The Wolvens killed my family, he said at last, and they wont stop until our entire bloodline is extinct.

text: Fayr could not believe what she was hearing.

text: I thought your mother died of illness.

text: And your brothers and sisters.

text: Poison.

text: How on earth did you survive.

text: Guards killed the assassin before he got to me.

text: Fayr tried to imagine it but she couldnt.

text: It was too terrible.

text: She didnt think things like that happened in Dearen.

text: How had her father carried this terrible memory within him, all of his life, while the rest of the world remained oblivious.

text: Why would anyone do that to you.

text: Who are the Wolvens.

text: King Joyhan turned to face his children, one eye catching the moonlight and glowing brightly.

text: A family bloodline, like our own, of which few remain.

text: They are known for their red eyes and profound lack of empathy for their fellow human beings.

text: I also suspect that like our own family, their ancestors made a pact with an ancient god.

text: Fayr blinked a few times.
Name: Book 28

text: Joyhan drank more from his flask, then put it away.

text: I dont understand.

text: Maybe thats how it should be, he said, breathing heavily.

text: * As she lay in bed that night, Fayr cradled her aching cheek and wondered about all her father had been through.
Name: Book 28

text: She had never really thought of it much before.
Name: Book 28

text: She had always feared him too much to wonder about such things.
Name: Book 28

text: Today, her fear of him dissipated.
Name: Book 28

text: Today, even though he had stricken her across the face, she did not feel afraid anymore.
Name: Book 28

text: She only felt angry.
Name: Book 28

text: How could he let Kyne discover the truth at the same time she did.
Name: Book 28

text: Kyne had only been asking questions for a few days now.
Name: Book 28

text: She had asked for some ten years or more.
Name: Book 28

text: Shed had no choice but to shut her mouth and force her mind into solitude.
Name: Book 28

text: She had drowned her emotions in the neverending struggle to seem happy, and as a result shed grown increasingly troubled and confused inside, for she never understood why she must do it.
Name: Book 28

text: Why couldnt she be happy like everyone else in the first place, always and without effort.
Name: Book 28

text: It was all her fathers fault.
Name: Book 28

text: He was a cruel and terrible man.

text: She had always known it, deep down, but she had never dwelt on it until now.
Name: Book 28

text: She had always been intimidated by his power and by the great secrets he harbored.

text: He was selfish and greedy, and he used his knowledge to control everyone else.
Name: Book 28

text: People would do anything to obtain happiness.

text: But if we had it already, why would we care.

text: She understood now what he meant by that.

text: King Joyhan used safra to control people, and his ancestors must have done the same.

text: Fayr should have figured out that much already.

text: Her own mother was the most obvious example.

text: Joyhan used safra to control Queen Lilyana all the time.

text: When Fayr was twelve years of age, she had discovered her father fornicating with a palace maid.

text: It had been quite an accident, and no fault of her own.

text: She had merely been wandering around the palace, twiddling her fingers and bored out of her mind.

text: Whenever she was bored she liked to walk down the Striped Corridor.
Name: Book 28

text: It was a hallway painted with gradient shades of orange, red, and gold.
Name: Book 28

text: Lashing these colors with sharp contrast were jagged stripes of black.
Name: Book 28

text: The entire corridor was made to mimic the fur of a tiger.

text: It was both gaudy and elegant, simple but magical, and whenever Fayr walked through the place, she felt as elegant as one of the great cats herself.
Name: Book 28

text: Yet on this day, she had glimpsed two figures far down the hall, locked together but undulating with movement.
Name: Book 28

text: She took a few steps closer before she realized what they were doing.
Name: Book 28

text: She had seen people have public sex before.
Name: Book 28

text: In Dearen, people rarely took the time to retreat to a private bedroom if the mood overcame them.
Name: Book 28

text: She witnessed it most often with visiting nobles, who would often become so exhilarated by the safra in their system that they no longer knew how to contain themselves.
Name: Book 28

text: But this was not a visiting noble.
Name: Book 28

text: Nor was it a foolish commoner.
Name: Book 28

text: It was her own father, and Fayr didnt realize it until she had merely passed them by.
Name: Book 28

text: There he was, his purple hair thrashing as he moved, his cheeks red and flushed, his hips pumping rhythmically towards this total stranger, who seemed so be-spelled by safra that she was half-asleep.

text: She shouldnt have said anything.
Name: Book 28

text: She just couldnt help herself.
Name: Book 28

text: She was so shocked by his behavior that her reaction came out unchecked.

text: But there was no mistaking the face that turned towards her.
Name: Book 28

text: King Joyhan paused, clutching the woman to him like a shield as he looked upon his daughter.
Name: Book 28

text: Get out of here, he snarled.
Name: Book 28

text: She fled, even though he stayed behind, apparently determined to finish what hed started.
Name: Book 28

text: When Fayr next encountered her father at dinner, he acted as if nothing had happened.

text: Fayr tried to convince herself of the same thing, that night and several thereafter.
Name: Book 28

text: But she could not forget her fathers flushed face, the maids glazed eyes.

text: And over time, the fact Joyhan acknowledged nothing bothered her more than anything else.

text: So at last, she confided in her mother.

text: A shadow had flickered over Queen Lilyanas face.
Name: Book 28

text: It was a strange sight, to say the least.
Name: Book 28

text: Lilyana almost always smiled.
Name: Book 28

text: Her face was practically stuck in that expression.
Name: Book 28

text: Yet all the sudden, her lips drooped, her nose tightened, and her brows knitted together.
Name: Book 28

text: Lets talk to your father about this, she said, and see what he has to say for himself.
Name: Book 28

text: For a fleeting moment, Fayr felt hopeful.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps whatever was about to happen would not be good, but at least it was something.

text: Anything to resolve the feelings stirring inside of her ever since she caught the king with the maid.

text: * Sean and his father lived on one of the most dangerous mountains in Vikand other than the Great Volcano itself.
Name: Book 28

text: For generations, members of the Wolven bloodline had lived here, for who else would want to.
Name: Book 28

text: The so-called Wolven mountain was notorious for its sharp granite spikes, its walls of white and gray foliated slate, and its jagged talus of broken obsidian around the base.
Name: Book 28

text: The small mountain held a plethora of fatal falls, flat unscalable surfaces, and mazes of black glassy stones that could distort ones vision and trap him forever in illusion.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean knew the path to his home because his father had trained him to traverse it as a small boy, and Sean had practiced it many times since.
Name: Book 28

text: The only other person who knew the same path was his sister, Shora, and she had left this continent for another long ago.
Name: Book 28

text: Sometimes, Sean looked forward to the climb homeward more than home itself.

text: He loved the solidity of the stone under his fingertips.

text: The path home would never change, unless the earth itself willed it.

text: Only an earthquake could morph the path, or perhaps an eruption of the far-off volcano, which had not erupted for centuries.
Name: Book 28

text: But no matter how often mortal men raged wars or built kingdoms, this mountain would stay the same.

text: Thats what he told himself, anyway, as the powdery slate rubbed the blood from his fingertips.

text: He would feel peaceful in his home, and he would not have a care as to what happened next.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps he would anticipate the day his father returned, sometimes with dread, sometimes with excitement.
Name: Book 28

text: Other times, he might look forward toor apprehendhis next inevitable assassination contract.
Name: Book 28

text: Until then, he would dwell in a lengthy and peaceable span of solitude.
Name: Book 28

text: This time, however, he had not even had time to adjust when the sound of a trumpet blasted over the mountain and awoke him from silence.
Name: Book 28

text: Normally, Sean would ignore such a sound.
Name: Book 28

text: Every once in awhile, people desiring the services of the Wolvens would blast their trumpets up the mountain in an attempt to lure one of them down.
Name: Book 28

text: Sometimes, Sean or his father would answer the call.
Name: Book 28

text: Most of the time, they did not.
Name: Book 28

text: This trumpet played a certain melody, however: one Sean recognized with a profound sense of dread.
Name: Book 28

text: It was the tune of the royal Polemarch, Leonard Khan himself.
Name: Book 28

text: He walked from his shack to the edge of the mountain bluff.
Name: Book 28

text: Far below, amidst the obsidian talus of the mountain, at least a hundred soldiers in their furs and plated armor awaited the Wolvens attention.
Name: Book 28

text: * A certain smell always hung about the Royal Horde, Sean had noticed.
Name: Book 28

text: It was not altogether good nor altogether bad, as far as he could tell, but a fluctuating mixture.
Name: Book 28

text: Depending on the strength of the breeze, one might catch a strong whiff of the ram-wool from the soldiers and archons important enough to ride them.
Name: Book 28

text: It was a bitter and musky smell, typically foul, but a smell Sean had known since childhood, and therefore not completely unpleasant.
Name: Book 28

text: Riding that odor in smaller but more potent splashes was the aroma of peppers and spices, for the Vikand royalty was notorious for its love of trenchant flavors.
Name: Book 28

text: Whatever his opinion on it, Sean did not have to breathe a great deal of the armys stench, for his wolf-mask protected him from its full pungency.
Name: Book 28

text: Really.
Name: Book 28

text: barked a gruff voice.
Name: Book 28

text: Youd wear that mask now.
Name: Book 28

text: The man who addressed him towered high above most other men.
Name: Book 28

text: His shoulders bulged from both muscle and armor.
Name: Book 28

text: Draga wool, the finest wool known to man and the hardest to obtain, draped his gold-plated armor in thick silver spirals.
Name: Book 28

text: Judging by this and the heavy gold rings wrapping his arms and neck, he was royalty.
Name: Book 28

text: His crisp blue eyes, coarse yellow hair, and boxy face provided yet another indication of his identity.
Name: Book 28

text: High Chief Richard, said Sean.
Name: Book 28

text: Why have you called me.
Name: Book 28

text: I didnt.
Name: Book 28

text: Richard jabbed a thumb in the direction of a large carriage behind him.
Name: Book 28

text: Metal rods and carvings framed the vehicle, showing off the best of Vikands metal-smithing.
Name: Book 28

text: Bear hides hung from the roof to form the walls.
Name: Book 28

text: Ropes bound two giant rams to the carriage, and their hooves scraped against the rocky earth as they stirred with impatience.
Name: Book 28

text: Their spiraling horns gleamed with sharp metal spikes.
Name: Book 28

text: My fathers the one who called you.
Name: Book 28

text: Leonard Khan.
Name: Book 28

text: No shit.
Name: Book 28

text: Now how about you tell me who you are.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean just stared at him blankly through the wolf mask.
Name: Book 28

text: He felt no need to point out the obvious.
Name: Book 28

text: You know what I mean, shit-brains.
Name: Book 28

text: Take off the mask.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean did not move, except for a few of his fingers that twitched against his side.

Name: Book 28

text: He would have loved to fling a throwing star into this idiots throat.
Name: Book 28

text: But today Sean wore a simple tunic and trousers, so only a knife and a few stars were stashed in his belt.
Name: Book 28

text: Besides, even if he wore his full outfit, he would not have enough stars to fight the Royal Horde.
Name: Book 28

text: To tell the truth, he felt out of sorts in this situation.
Name: Book 28

text: The few times royalty had come to call in the past, his father had been the one to answer them.
Name: Book 28

text: And even then, the meetings had been discreet.
Name: Book 28

text: A hundred hordesfolk had not marched to Wolven mountain just to give him an assignment.
Name: Book 28

text: So what on earth could this be about.
Name: Book 28

text: I said take off the mask.
Name: Book 28

text: Richard grabbed the hilt of his sword.
Name: Book 28

text: It was a giant thing, nearly the width of his bulging arms, and the edge was serrated.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean did not reach for his own weapon, but slightly adjusted his balance.
Name: Book 28

text: The quickest way to best this oaf would be to use his own momentum against him.
Name: Book 28

text: Richard, please hold your temper.
Name: Book 28

text: A new man stepped down from the carriage.
Name: Book 28

text: His face and coloring shared some aspect of Richards, but in all other things they were opposite.
Name: Book 28

text: While Richards skin was leathery and coarse with hair, this fellow had the complexion of a babys; his round cheeks shone a rosy pink.
Name: Book 28

text: He even had dimples.
Name: Book 28

text: His blond hair was short and curly, as if casting a golden halo about his head.
Name: Book 28

text: He wore no armor of any sort: only soft white linens.
Name: Book 28

text: He lacked the muscular build of most men of Vikand; his framesmall though it wasmore closely resembled the suppleness of freshly baked bread.
Name: Book 28

text: Forgive my brother, wont you.
Name: Book 28

text: said the younger fellow, swaggering closer.
Name: Book 28

text: He tends to draw his steel prematurely.
Name: Book 28

text: As well as thrust it.
Name: Book 28

text: You mustnt fault him for it.
Name: Book 28

text: He has been rewarded for such behavior all his life.
Name: Book 28

text: As have you, I imagine.
Name: Book 28

text: Picard grinned as if this clever observation should make them all friends.
Name: Book 28

text: Then he put one fist against his chest and bowed slightly in the traditional gesture of respect.
Name: Book 28

text: The right arm remained at his side, as it should, but in this position Sean noticed something strange about it.
Name: Book 28

text: The arm seemed strangely shaped, as if the joints were uneven, and it also seemed disproportionately small.
Name: Book 28

text: He wore a black leather glove on his hand that disappeared up his white sleeve.
Name: Book 28

text: Buckles and straps covered the glove, criss-crossing every which way, and Sean also caught the glint of metal under gaps in the fabric.
Name: Book 28

text: His other hand, meanwhile, seemed completely normal.
Name: Book 28

text: I am Archon Picard, the young politician went on.
Name: Book 28

text: Our father is Polemarch Leonard, also the khan of all Vikand.
Name: Book 28

text: And you are a Wolven.
Name: Book 28

text: He took a step closer, squinting his big blue eyes.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean noticed something odd about them.
Name: Book 28

text: His eyes had a flatness to them, like staring into a stirred pond before the dirt settled.
Name: Book 28

text: The gaze had no depth, or if it did, Sean could not determine it.
Name: Book 28

text: Wont you tell us your name.
Name: Book 28

text: All you need to know is that I am Wolven.
Name: Book 28

text: And if you have an assignment for me, you must tell me quickly, or I will return home.
Name: Book 28

text: Will you now.
Name: Book 28

text: Picard and his brother exchanged glances.
Name: Book 28

text: Then Picard chuckled, as if sharing a joke with his brother, and snapped his fingers.
Name: Book 28

text: Not much could startle Sean, but when Picard snapped his fingers, the Wolven flinched slightly.
Name: Book 28

text: Picard made the motion with his right hand: the same hand wearing the ridiculous glove.
Name: Book 28

text: If Sean had thought the arm was oddly-shaped before, he now hesitated to call it an arm at all.
Name: Book 28

text: It did not move the way an arm should move.

frame.Frame: Cause change of position on a scale
Cause change of position on a scale

Name: Book 28

text: When the fingers snapped, they moved with uncanny swiftness, and made a clicking sound as if from within the flesh itself.
Name: Book 28

text: Finally, Sean had noticed that just before snapping, Picard had pulled a strap of his glove with his other handalmost like a trigger to set off the motion.
Name: Book 28

text: In any case, no one else seemed surprised by this, and a servant nearby even seemed to expect it.
Name: Book 28

text: He walked up to Picard with a flint at the ready.
Name: Book 28

text: Picard pulled a gray cigar from his tunic with his normal hand and held it up to the lackey.
Name: Book 28

text: As the lackey struck the flint, Picard caught the spark, then sucked the cigar with great fervor.
Name: Book 28

text: A flame caught and glowed red.
Name: Book 28

text: When Picard exhaled, glittering smoke poured from his lips.
Name: Book 28

text: There, he said, his cheeks dimpling with a happy smile.
Name: Book 28

text: Now what were we talking about.
Name: Book 28

text: I wanted to be polite and let you introduce yourself, but you dont seem so inclined.
Name: Book 28

text: Your name is Sean Wolven.
Name: Book 28

text: Your father was Gray Wolven.
Name: Book 28

text: He did not fulfill the most important assignment of his life, and so you have inherited it out of necessity.
Name: Book 28

text: He took another drag on his cigar, and for just a moment, the glitter of the smoke seemed to catch in his gaze.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean felt cold inside.
Name: Book 28

text: He did not know how Picard knew his full name.
Name: Book 28

text: But never mind that: a name was just a name.
Name: Book 28

text: This didnt trouble him so much as the rest.
Name: Book 28

text: What happened to my father.
Name: Book 28

text: If you want to know, said Picard, take off the mask and meet the Polemarch in his carriage.
Name: Book 28

text: What does the mask matter anyway.
Name: Book 28

text: I already know your nameas does everyone in hearing rangeand even if I didnt, I suspect I could pick you out of any crowd by those red eyes of yours.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean wanted to take it off anyway.
Name: Book 28

text: He could not see straight through the holes and his breath felt stifled by the ceramic.
Name: Book 28

text: He only wore it because he thought it was expected of him, both by family tradition and royal etiquette.
Name: Book 28

text: Often, hiring a face-less assassin seemed like a good idea for both parties involved.
Name: Book 28

text: But perhaps Picard was right.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps there wasnt a point anymore.
Name: Book 28

text: Ill take the mask off once Im in the carriage, he said at last.
Name: Book 28

text: Beads of sweat tickled Seans brow.
Name: Book 28

text: What else could he do.
Name: Book 28

text: Call Picards bluff and leave this all behind to climb back up the mountain.
Name: Book 28

text: Or do whatever he asked and learn more.
Name: Book 28

text: His hand trembled as he grabbed the mask and began to pull.
Name: Book 28

text: A welcome breeze splashed his face as he bared it.
Name: Book 28

text: He lowered the mask to his side and reluctantly met Picards gaze.

frame.Frame: Cause change of position on a scale

Name: Book 28

text: Very good, said Picard.
Name: Book 28

text: The archons expression increased Seans dread.

text: Picard looked more pleased than he ought to, as if he had won a much greater battle.
Name: Book 28

text: Now into the carriage.
Name: Book 28

text: But as we go, I suppose I should forewarn you of one little fact.
Name: Book 28

text: Your father is dead.
Name: Book 28

text: He could not remember the last time in his entire life he had staggered.

text: Picard watched it happen, for even as he pretended to shift his attention, his eyes fixed on Sean, and for a moment they looked like clear, bottomless pools.
Name: Book 28

text: * What else did you tell him.
Name: Book 28

text: grumbled Leonard Khan.

text: What the hell did the two of you say.

text: Within the carriage, Sean could hardly breathe, much less keep his wits about him.
Name: Book 28

Name: Book 28

text: It was so dark that he could have kept his mask on and no one would have known the difference.

text: The khan himself was just a bright blur in the corner.
Name: Book 28

text: Only one candle burned next to him, and this barely illuminated his bear-skin clothes, his Khan Collar of rubies and steel, and his stark white hair.
Name: Book 28

text: Meanwhile, the strange smoke from Picards cigar filled the carriage with its glittery billows, and something about its smell bothered Sean very much.
Name: Book 28

text: His nose itched and his head spun.
Name: Book 28

text: If youre unhappy with my performance, Picard told his father, then next time do it yourself.
Name: Book 28

text: Yes I will, growled the khan, then Ill strip you of your archonship.

text: Picard chuckled, pouring out another stream of smoke.

text: I look forward to the day.

text: The khan coughed and turned back to Sean, who still knelt awkwardly on the metal floor of the carriage.

Name: Book 28

text: That is not for me to say.

text: Well, sighed the khan and Polemarch, I really dont give a shit anyway.

text: All I care about is whether youre as devoted as your father to wiping the Violenese family from the face of the earth.

text: Sean bowed his head, wishing more than ever that he wore a mask just to hide his torn expression.

text: What could he say.

text: His father had always taught him that an employer should never know a Wolvens feelings at all.

text: I am committed to my assignments, he said.

text: It is as simple as that.

text: Leonard Khan made a little grunt of uncertainty.

text: Picard stepped forward between his father and Sean.
Name: Book 28

text: I think this is a very good response.

text: I have heard that the relationship between the Wolvens and Violenese has often been misunderstood, anyway.

text: They were merely very good at it, and because the Violenese posed such a problem for others, they became a common assignment for the Wolvens.

text: Others believe your families were enemies long ago because you worshiped opposing gods.

text: He did not like the fact Picard addressed him by his first name.

text: Isnt that right, Father.

text: Sean lowered his head even further.

text: Isnt that right, Sean.

text: asked Leonard Khan.

text: Hm.

Name: Book 28

text: Sean bowed, then all but ran out the carriage.
Name: Book 28

text: * Sean waited for his payment at the top of the obsidian scree slope.
Name: Book 28

text: As much as he wanted to be home and preparing his fire by now, he felt a certain satisfaction standing here above the army.
Name: Book 28

text: He wondered whether his father would have been proud of his performance today, his first real encounter with royalty.
Name: Book 28

text: His heart twinged with pain as he realized he would never know what his father thought.
Name: Book 28

text: He would never see his father again.
Name: Book 28

text: The physical sensations of his surroundings helped distract him from inner confusion.
Name: Book 28

text: A gushing breeze flapped his tunic against his legs and lashed his dark hair against his cheek.
Name: Book 28

text: The sun cast a red glow upon the mountainous horizon as it sank, pushing long skinny shadows over the gray earth.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean thought to himself that if the shadows were tangible, they would slice the Royal Horde apart.
Name: Book 28

text: Flames sprouted from darkness as the Horde lit their torches.

text: Hammers thrust pins into the rocky earth as they hastened to pitch a few tents.

text: Whether they had intended to stay the night here or not, it appeared that they would.

text: Eventually a pale shape distinguished itself from the writhing mass of hordesfolk and picked its way up the rocks.

text: Sean took a deep breath in preparation.
Name: Book 28

Name: Book 28

text: Sean did not like most people.
Name: Book 28

text: And when Eleanor demanded to see Princess Fayr, they just told her to wait in the Quartz Courtyard with dozens of other suitors.

text: They told herthe King-wife of Yamair herself.

text: that the princess would summon her when the princess was ready: perhaps today, perhaps tomorrow, perhaps never.

text: Eleanor did not know what else she expected.
Name: Book 28

text: A few times, she had even looked forward to making this trip to Dearen.
Name: Book 28

text: But in those situations, she had let her emotions get the better of her.
Name: Book 28

text: Now, she saw this place for the pathetic establishment that it was.

text: King-wife Eleanor of Yamair, said a guard.

text: Princess Fayr summons you to the Crystal Dining Hall.

text: Based on how long people in this courtyard and other areas of the palace had been waitingdays, at leastEleanor had begun to worry.
Name: Book 28

text: Here in the Quartz Courtyard, various suitors claimed to have been waiting to see the princess for weeks: Vikand chiefs wearing wool and axes, Dearen knights swollen with fat and jewelry, and even a few Yamairan Synergists who tried to hide their presence from the King-wife behind fountains and women.
Name: Book 28

text: The number of women in the courtyard nearly equaled that of men.
Name: Book 28

text: Eleanor did not understand why, at first, but after a few dreadful hours of observation, she began to comprehend.
Name: Book 28

text: The women here helped occupy the men during the long days or weeks of waiting ahead of them.
Name: Book 28

text: In fact, from what Eleanor could tell, they provided much too good a distraction.
Name: Book 28

text: Was it possible to do something too effectively.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps so, if the action pushed towards a different purpose than originally intended.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps these women did not just want to entertain the men: perhaps they courted the men so that they might grab for themselves whomever the Princess rejected.
Name: Book 28

text: Or perhaps they had no objective at all, and that was why Eleanors head hurt trying to find one.
Name: Book 28

text: Perhaps they were all simply fools, kissing and groping each other without any concern for the outcome.
Name: Book 28

text: A few of the Vikand horsewomen made use of the Dearen men as surely as the hordesmen used the Dearen women.
Name: Book 28

text: They straddled the males or pulled them on top of them, guiding their movements to their hearts content.
Name: Book 28

text: Is this what safra did to people.
Name: Book 28

text: The most blatant displays of debauchery came from the khan of Vikands own family.
Name: Book 28

text: Eleanor identified the khan by the thick metal jewelry he wore about his neck, or so-called Khan Collar.
Name: Book 28

text: He was a large man draped with furs and Vikand metalwork, whose confidence of presence suggested his political status.
Name: Book 28

text: He sat surrounded by women who poured him drinks and ran their fingers over the bare flesh of his arms.
Name: Book 28

text: After the women teased him long enough, he pulled one onto his lap and bounced her there for awhile.

text: Eleanor found it so distasteful that she forced herself to look away.
Name: Book 28

text: Looking away did not help matters, unfortunately, for her eyes fell next on the khans own sonor so she suspected, based on their resemblance.

text: This large man did not even demonstrate the slight decency of his father.

text: He pulled a woman onto his lap who wore a loose satin gown.
Name: Book 28

text: He kissed her mouth with big motions of his lips and tongue.
Name: Book 28

text: Then he reached between them and unbuckled his own trousers.
Name: Book 28

text: What do you think of my brother.

text: Hes a cad, is he not.

text: He had curly blond hair to his ears, whisking about his face in a hundred directions.
Name: Book 28

text: He had a face like a babys, soft and round, with dimples that cut into his cheeks when he smiled.
Name: Book 28

text: But strangest of all was his right hand, which he extended towards her while she was still trying to think of a reply.

text: Archon Picard at your service.
Name: Book 28

text: King-wife Eleanor.

text: She gripped the hand reluctantly, for it was covered by a long leather glove stretching up to his elbow.

text: Straps and buckles weaved in and out of the leather in various spots, as if to connect with metal rods in his flesh.

text: She confirmed this as she felt his joints moving under her grip: they were of a harder make than bone, even though some fingers were still soft with flesh.

text: After a moment she realized she had been holding the hand longer than etiquette permitted, but now her curiosity had peaked.

text: Was it made in Yamair.

text: Thats an interesting question.

text: He lifted his hand from her, curling the fingers inward.

text: Where did my hand came from.

text: It came from Dearen, for I was on safra when I strolled into combat and got my arm crushed to pieces.

text: His smiled tightened as he continued to move his fingers, in and out, in and out.

Name: Book 28

text: When he saw the state of my arm and I refused to let him remove it, he offered to try and fix it.

text: His gaze returned to her, glittering like the safra in the air.
Name: Book 28

text: So you might say I am a product of all Three Nations.

text: As he drifted away, he left Eleanor with a strange sense of foreboding.

text: A hood hung over his face, which he kept bowed in shadow.

text: But at least the robe itself was a sight to behold: intricate embroidery covered every inch of the fabric, designed to imitate the inner workings of Yamairs finest machinery.

text: Are you going to lead us to the princess, or shall I find her on my own.

Name: Book 28

text: Eleanor stopped out of necessity to let her eyes adjust to the brilliance of the chamber.

text: Light shone everywhere, reflecting off almost every imaginable surface, and the Haze in the air made it worse.

text: Then she saw the shapes of the prince and princess of Dearen.
Name: Book 28

text: She knew them instantly by their lush purple hair.

text: They sat together on one end of the four-sided table, backs straight, faces flat.
Name: Book 28

text: Their youth was remarkable: Prince Kyne hardly appeared to be thirteen years of age, and the princess less than twenty.
Name: Book 28

text: Nonetheless, something about the princess demanded immediate respect.
Name: Book 28

text: Her hair rolled up over her head where it spread out like a fan, its lavender strands intertwined with pink and yellow flowers.
Name: Book 28

text: Safra dusted her pale skin, twinkling slightly with the movement of the light around her.
Name: Book 28

text: A soft white dress covered her body, but only in the way that clouds might be said to cover the sky, gently and freely.

text: Her face and body was without a doubt the most beautiful Eleanor had ever seen in her life, and she needed no emotions to think so.
Name: Book 28

text: Physically-speaking, the princess represented pure  perfection.

text: May I present Queen Eleanor of Yamair, said the guard, and, er, her companions.

text: My title is King-wife, said Eleanor, although for the briefest of moments, she wondered why.

text: Have a seat at my table.

text: * Eleanor strolled through the Gardens of Delight and marveled at every flower and vine in sight.

text: If I am not there by then, go to the tree in the Shadowed Woods where we first put a splint on your wrist.

text: I.

text: Chief.

text: Good luck to you, master.

text: Sean nodded, then forged onward.
Name: Book 28

text: * As he followed the rippling light of Kynes cloak, Sean continued contemplating all that had happened and all that might happen next.
Name: Book 28

text: He had to kill Prince Kyne.
Name: Book 28

text: He had no choice.
Name: Book 28

text: He had delayed as long as possible, but he could feel Belazars power starting to drain him even as it strengthened him.
Name: Book 28

text: It fed him energy while depleting his own physical resources.
Name: Book 28

text: Eventually it would feed off Seans own body if Sean did not deliver the life hed promised.
Name: Book 28

text: Or, if it came to that, Sean suspected he might lose the will to control his body first.
Name: Book 28

text: Belazar might use his body as an instrument to take the prince for himself.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean was not sure which would happen, but he knew that Belazarif Belazar was truly a conscious entitywould not stay patient much longer.
Name: Book 28

text: This is it, said Prince Kyne.
Name: Book 28

text: He stood at the door of the dungeons, the key in his hand, trembling.
Name: Book 28

text: Sean released the bundle and stared curiously at the face of the door.
Name: Book 28

text: It was made of stone, yet carved and smoothed with incredible skill.
Name: Book 28

text: The shapes of serpents and vines flowed in and out of the stone, like living bodies that had been frozen in time.
Name: Book 28

text: One large tiger roamed amongst them, as did a wolf.
Name: Book 28

text: The tigers roaring mouth opened into the gap of the keyhole.
Name: Book 28

text: Then Sean noticed a mask hanging from the wall next to the door.
Name: Book 28

text: He flinched and drew back, for the mask was in the gaudy shape of a wolf.
Name: Book 28

text: At some point, the ceramic had been broken into several pieces, then pasted back together.
Name: Book 28

text: Prince Kyne followed his gaze.
Name: Book 28

text: Thats the mask of the Wolven who tried to kill me, said the prince.
Name: Book 28

text: Fayr killed him, put his mask back together, and hung it here so wed never forget about him.
Name: Book 28

text: Seans fingers dug fiercely into the fabric of the tapestry.
Name: Book 28

text: He had wondered once what could have defeated his father in a place like this.
Name: Book 28

text: Princess Fayr had been his fathers undoing, and she would be Seans, if he was not careful.
Name: Book 28

text: Unlock the fucking door, said Sean.
Name: Book 28

text: Kyne flinched at his tone, but finally moved.
